title: In Holocaust remembrance , Biden condemns antisemitism sparked by college protests and Gaza war
message:
In Holocaust remembrance, Biden condemns antisemitism sparked by college protests and Gaza warWASHINGTON (AP) — President Joe Biden on Tuesday decried a “ferocious surge” in antisemitism on college campuses and around the globe in the months since Hamas attacked Israel and triggered a war in Gaza, using a ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust to also denounce new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.
But it played out in counterpoint to former President Donald Trump’s criticism of the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism.
He added, “We’re not a lawless country — we are a civil society”In conjunction with Biden’s speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond.
And the State Department’s special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.
Trump’s campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel’s Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates’ responses on antisemitism.

title: Biden condemns  ferocious surge of antisemitism  in Holocaust remembrance speech

“We’re at risk of people not knowing the truth,” Mr Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators.
“As Jews around the world still cope with the atrocity and trauma of that day and its aftermath, we’ve seen a ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world,” Mr Biden said.
Mr Biden said “There’s no place on any campus in America” or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence.

title: Biden to call for a fight against antisemitism at a precarious moment in Israel war in Gaza and amid protests on campus
message:
Washington CNN —President Joe Biden on Tuesday issued a call to fight a “ferocious surge” of antisemitism, saying such hate has no place in America as he connected the horrors of the Holocaust to Hamas’ attack on Israel.
Biden’s speech was a somber – yet impassioned – moment of reflection amid a tense and pivotal time in his reelection push.
He cited specific reports from Jewish students of being physically assaulted or harassed while walking on campus, antisemitic statements, including that Jewish students should “go back to Poland,” verbal abuse and swastikas found on dorm room doors.
On Monday, a day ahead of Biden’s speech, second gentleman Doug Emhoff hosted a number of Jewish students at the White House for a roundtable.
Biden’s speech came one day after Yom HaShoah, or Holocaust Remembrance Day.

title: Biden condemns surge of antisemitism since Oct . 7 Hamas attacks on Israel : NPR
message:
Biden decries surge of antisemitism since the October 7 Hamas attacks on IsraelEnlarge this image toggle caption Saul Loeb/AFP via Getty Images Saul Loeb/AFP via Getty ImagesPresident Biden condemned antisemitic incidents on college campuses in a speech during a solemn event at the U.S. Capitol on Tuesday: the Days of Remembrance for the 6 million Jews killed in the Holocaust.
Biden drew a line from the atrocities in the Holocaust to the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks in Israel, and said what has followed that day has been despicable.
"We've seen a ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world," Biden said.
"But there is no place on any campus in America — any place in America — for antisemitism or hate speech, or threats of violence or any kind," he said.
Enlarge this image toggle caption Saul Loeb/AFP via Getty Images Saul Loeb/AFP via Getty ImagesThe president often describes his father at the dinner table teaching the family about the horrors of the Holocaust.
